--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:

> >
> Well good luck with that. I think this may actually be the first 
non 
> neural net use of NEAT, unless Ken knows otherwise. I know he's 
often 
> mentioned that the NEAT technique isn't constrained to just ANN's.
> 

Actually a few non-neural things have been done, though they aren't 
widely known. Stephanie Forrest at University of New Mexico had her 
grad class evolve finite state automata with a subset of NEAT.  
There was a student at Michigan State who did a NEAT-like evolution 
of fuzzy controller logic.  A group in Brazil evolved RBF networks 
using complexification, and a student in Romania evolved Bayesian 
networks using NEAT.  Finally, Nate Kohl, a Ph.D. student here at UT 
Austin, actually created a NEAT-based L-system indirect encoding 
evolution system for objects (not NNs), but I don't think he's 
pursuing that anymore, though I thought it was a very cool system.
I'm probably forgetting some others.

Anyway, the RETE stuff is totally new to me, and looks like a 
promising domain for NEAT.  I'm kind of intererested, Greg, if you 
could summarize a little how the RETE networks are currently built?  
Is it by hand, or through some deterministic process?  And what are 
the flaws with the current way of building them that NEAT might 
overcome?  Do the RETE networks currently tend to be suboptimal in 
some way?

ken
